knife.lazy.lazyknife — Lazily evaluated combo knife¶

class knife.lazy.lazyknife(*things, **kw)[source]¶

Lazily evaluated combo knife.

all()¶

Discover if worker() returns True for every incoming thing.

>>> from knife import __
>>> __(2, 4, 6, 8).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).all().fetch()
True
any()¶

Discover if worker() returns True for any incoming thing.

>>> __(1, 4, 5, 9).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).any().fetch()
True
append(*things)¶

Insert things after other incoming things.

Parameters:things – incoming things 
>>> __(3, 4, 5).append(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[3, 4, 5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
argmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each incoming thing to worker() as wildcard positional arguments.

Parameters:merge (boolean) –

merge global positional params() with positional arguments derived from an iterable

>>> from knife import __
>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __((1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4))
>> test.worker(lambda x, y: x * y).argmap().fetch()
[2, 6, 12]
>>> # merge global positional arguments with iterable arguments
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x, y, z, a, b: x * y * z * a * b)
>>> test.params(7, 8, 9).argmap(merge=True).fetch()
[1008, 3024, 6048]
ascii(errors='strict')¶

byte encode outgoing things with the 'ascii' codec.

Parameters:errors (string) –

error handling for decoding issues

>>> from knife import __
>>> from stuf.six import u, b
>>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.ascii().wrap_each().peek()
(b('[1]'), b('True'), b('t'), b('i'), b('g'), b('None'), b('(1,)'))
at(n, default=None)¶

Slice off incoming thing found at index n.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – index of some incoming thing
  • default –

    default returned if nothing is found at n

    >>> from knife import __
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(2).fetch()
3
>>> # return default value if nothing found at index
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(10, 11).fetch()
11
attributes(*names)¶

Collect attribute values from incoming things that match an attribute name found in names.

Parameters:names (string) –

attribute names

>>> from knife import __
>>> from stuf import stuf
>>> stooge = [
...    stuf(name='moe', age=40),
...    stuf(name='larry', age=50),
...    stuf(name='curly', age=60),
... ]
>>> __(*stooge).attributes('name').fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> # multiple attribute names
>>> __(*stooge).attributes('name', 'age').fetch()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # no attributes named 'place'
>>> __(*stooge).attributes('place').fetch()
[]
average()¶

Discover average incoming thing.

>>> from knife import __
>>> __(10, 40, 45).average().fetch()
31.666666666666668
baseline()¶

Restore incoming things to baseline snapshot().

>>> from knife import __
>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> undone.snapshot().append(1).append(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2]
>>> undone.baseline().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
bytes(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

byte encode outgoing things.

Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) –

    error handling for encoding issues

    >>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.bytes().wrap_each().peek()
(b('[1]'), b('True'), b('t'), b('i'), b('g'), b('None'), b('(1,)'))
choice()¶

Randomly slice off one incoming thing.

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).choice().fetch()
3
clear()¶

Clear everything.

combinations(n)¶

Discover combinations of every n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) –

number of incoming things to generate combinations from

>>> from knife import __
>>> __(40, 50, 60).combinations(2).fetch()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 60)]
copy()¶

Duplicate each incoming thing.

>>> __([[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]).copy().fetch()
[[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]
count()¶

Discover how many times each incoming thing occurs.

Returns:tuple of (least common thing, most common thing, [counts of everything (a list of tuple pairs of (thing, count))]).
>>> common = __(11, 3, 5, 11, 7, 3, 5, 11).count().fetch()
>>> # least common thing
>>> common.least_common
7
>>> # most common thing
>>> common.most_common
11
>>> # total count for every thing
>>> common.totals
[(11, 3), (3, 2), (5, 2), (7, 1)]
dice(n, fill=None)¶

Slice one iterable incoming thing into n iterable incoming things.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of incoming things per slice
  • fill – value to pad out incomplete iterables
 
>>> __('moe', 'larry', 'curly', 30, 40, 50, True).dice(2, 'x').fetch()
[('moe', 'larry'), ('curly', 30), (40, 50), (True, 'x')]
difference(symmetric=False)¶

Discover difference within a series of iterable incoming things.

Parameters:symmetric (boolean) – use symmetric difference 
>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], [5, 2, 10], [10, 11, 2])
>>> test.difference().fetch()
[1, 3, 4]
>>> # symmetric difference
>>> test.original().difference(symmetric=True).fetch()
[1, 3, 4, 11]
duality()¶

Divide incoming things into two iterables, the first being everything worker() evaluates as True and the second being everything worker() evaluates as False.

>>> test = __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
>>> divide = test.duality().fetch()
>>> divide.true
[2, 4, 6]
>>> divide.false
[1, 3, 5]
fetch()¶

Return outgoing things wrapped with wrap().

filter(invert=False)¶

Collect incoming things matched by worker().

Parameters:invert (boolean) –

collect incoming things worker() evaluates as False instead of True

>>> # filter for true values
>>> test = __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
>>> test.filter().fetch()
[2, 4, 6]
>>> # filter for false values
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
>>> test.filter(invert=True).fetch()
[1, 3, 5]
first(n=0)¶

Slice off n things from the starting end of incoming things or just the first incoming thing.

Parameters:n (integer) –

number of incoming things

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first().fetch()
5
>>> # first things from index 0 to 2
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first(2).fetch()
[5, 4]
flatten()¶

Reduce nested incoming things to flattened incoming things.

>>> from knife import __
>>> __([[1, [2], [3, [[4]]]], 'here']).flatten().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 'here']
group()¶

Group incoming things using worker() as the key function.

>>> from knife import __
>>> # default grouping
>>> __(1.3, 2.1, 2.4).group().fetch()
[(1.3, (1.3,)), (2.1, (2.1,)), (2.4, (2.4,))]
>>> from math import floor
>>> # use worker for key function
>>> __(1.3, 2.1, 2.4).worker(floor).group().fetch()
[(1.0, (1.3,)), (2.0, (2.1, 2.4))]
initial()¶

Slice off everything except the last incoming thing.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).initial().fetch()
[5, 4, 3, 2]
intersection()¶

Discover intersection within a series of iterable incoming things.

>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).intersection().fetch()
[1, 2]
invoke(name)¶

Call method name from each incoming thing with the global positional and keyword params() but keep the original thing if the return value of the method call is None.

Parameters:name (string) –

method name

>>> # invoke list.index()
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).params(1).invoke('index').fetch()
[1, 2]
>>> # invoke list.sort() but return sorted list instead of None
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).invoke('sort').fetch()
[[1, 5, 7], [1, 2, 3]]
items(*keys)¶

Collect values from incoming things (usually sequences or mappings) that match a key found in keys.

Parameters:keys (string) –

keys or indices

>>> stooge = [
...    dict(name='moe', age=40),
...    dict(name='larry', age=50),
...    dict(name='curly', age=60)
... ]
>>> # get items from mappings like dictionaries, etc...
>>> __(*stooge).items('name').fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items('name', 'age').fetch()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # get items from sequences like lists, tuples, etc...
>>> stooge = [['moe', 40], ['larry', 50], ['curly', 60]]
>>> __(*stooge).items(0).fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items(1).fetch()
[40, 50, 60]
>>> __(*stooge).items('place').fetch()
[]
kwargmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each incoming thing as a tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments to worker().

Parameters:merge (boolean) –

merge global positional or keyword params() with positional and keyword arguments derived from an iterable into a single tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments like (iterable_args + global_args, global_kwargs + iterable_kwargs)

>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __(
...  ((1, 2), {'a': 2}), ((2, 3), {'a': 2}), ((3, 4), {'a': 2})
... )
>>> test.worker(test).kwargmap().fetch()
[6, 10, 14]
>>> def tester(*args, **kw):
...    return sum(args) * sum(kw.values())
>>> # merging global and iterable derived positional and keyword args
>>> test.original().worker(tester).params(1, 2, 3, b=5, w=10, y=13)
>>> test.kwargmap(merge=True).fetch()
[270, 330, 390]
last(n=0)¶

Slice off n things from the tail end of incoming things or just the last incoming thing.

Parameters:n (integer) –

number of incoming things

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last().fetch()
1
>>> # fetch last two things
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last(2).fetch()
[2, 1]
map()¶

Feed each incoming thing to worker().

>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x: x * 3).map().fetch()
[3, 6, 9]
mapping(keys=False, values=False)¶

Run worker() on incoming mapping things.

Parameters:
  • keys (boolean) – collect mapping keys only
  • values (boolean) –

    collect mapping values only

    >>> # filter items
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).worker(lambda x, y: x * y).mapping().fetch()
[2, 6, 12, 2, 6, 12]
>>> # mapping keys only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(keys=True).fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # mapping values only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(values=True).fetch()
[2, 3, 4, 2, 3, 4]
max()¶

Discover maximum incoming thing using worker() as the key function.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 4).max().fetch()
4
>>> stooges = (
...    {'name': 'moe', 'age': 40},
...    {'name': 'larry', 'age': 50},
...    {'name': 'curly', 'age': 60},
... )
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(*stooges).worker(lambda x: x['age']).max().fetch()
{'age': 60, 'name': 'curly'}
median()¶

Discover median incoming thing.

>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1).median().fetch()
4
>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1, 8).median().fetch()
4.5
merge()¶

Reduce multiple iterable incoming things into one iterable incoming thing.

>>> test = __(['moe', 'larry'], [30, 40], [True, False])
test.merge().fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 30, 40, True, False]
min()¶

Discover minimum incoming thing using worker() as the key function.

>>> test = __(10, 5, 100, 2, 1000)
>>> test.min().fetch()
2
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x: x % 100 == 0).min().fetch()
10
minmax()¶

Discover minimum and maximum incoming things.

Returns:namedtuple (minimum value, maximum value).
>>> minmax = __(1, 2, 4).minmax().fetch()
>>> minmax.minimum
1
>>> minmax.maximum
4
original()¶

Restore incoming things to original snapshot.

>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> undone.original().peek()
[1, 2, 3]
params(*args, **kw)¶

Assign positional and keyword arguments used whenever worker() is invoked.

pattern(pattern, type='parse', flags=0)¶

Compile search pattern for use as worker().

Parameters:
  • pattern (string) – search pattern
  • type (string) – engine to compile pattern with. Valid options are ‘parse’, ‘re’, or ‘glob’
  • flags (integer) –

    regular expression flags

    >>> # using parse expression
>>> test = __('first test', 'second test', 'third test')
>>> test.pattern('first {}').filter().fetch()
'first test'
>>> # using regular expression
>>> test.original().pattern('third .', type='regex').filter().fetch()
'third test'
>>> # using glob pattern
>>> test.original().pattern('second*', type='glob').filter().fetch()
'second test'
peek()¶

Preview current incoming things wrapped with wrap().

permutations(n)¶

Discover permutations of every n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) –

number of incoming things to generate permutations from

>>> __(40, 50, 60).permutations(2).fetch()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 40), (50, 60), (60, 40), (60, 50)]
prepend(*things)¶

Insert things before other incoming things.

Parameters:things – incoming things 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __(3, 4, 5).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 3, 4, 5]
range()¶

Discover length of the smallest interval that can contain every incoming thing.

>>> __(3, 5, 7, 3, 11).range().fetch()
8
reduce(initial=None, reverse=False)¶

Reduce iterable incoming things down to one incoming thing using worker().

Parameters:
  • initial – starting value
  • reverse (boolean) –

    reduce from the right side of incoming things

    >>> # reduce from left side
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce().fetch(),
6
>>> # reduce from left side with initial value
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce(1).fetch()
7
>>> # reduce from right side
>>> test = __([0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5]).worker(lambda x, y: x + y)
>>> test.reduce(reverse=True).fetch()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1]
>>> # reduce from right side with initial value
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x, y: x + y)
>>> test.reduce(initial=[0, 0], reverse=True).fetch()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1, 0, 0]
repeat(n=None, call=False)¶

Repeat either incoming things or invoke worker() n times.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of times to repeat
  • call (boolean) –

    repeat results of invoking worker()

    >>> # repeat iterable
>>> __(40, 50, 60).repeat(3).fetch()
[(40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60)]
>>> def test(*args):
...    return list(args)
>>> # with worker
>>> __(40, 50, 60).worker(test).repeat(n=3, call=True).fetch()
[[40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60]]
rest()¶

Slice off everything except the first incoming thing.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).rest().fetch()
[4, 3, 2, 1]
reverse()¶

Reverse the order of incoming things.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).reverse().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
sample(n)¶

Randomly slice off n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) –

sample size

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).sample(3).fetch()
[2, 4, 5]
shuffle()¶

Randomly sort incoming things.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).shuffle().fetch()
[3, 1, 5, 4, 2]
slice(start, stop=False, step=False)¶

Slice incoming things.

Parameters:
  • start (integer) – starting index of slice
  • stop (integer) – stopping index of slice
  • step (integer) –

    size of step in slice

    >>> # slice from index 0 to 3
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2).fetch()
[5, 4]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4).fetch()
[3, 2]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4 with 2 steps
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4, 2).fetch()
3
snapshot()¶

Take baseline snapshot of current incoming things.

sort()¶

Reorder incoming things using worker() as the key function.

>>> # default sort
>>> __(4, 6, 65, 3, 63, 2, 4).sort().fetch()
[2, 3, 4, 4, 6, 63, 65]
>>> from math import sin
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(sin).sort().fetch()
[5, 4, 6, 3, 1, 2]
sum(start=0, precision=False)¶

Discover total by adding start and incoming things together.

Parameters:
  • start (integer or float) – starting number
  • precision (boolean) –

    add floats with extended precision

    >>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum().fetch()
6
>>> # with a starting mumber
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum(start=1).fetch()
7
>>> # add floating points with extended precision
>>> __(.1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1).sum(precision=True).fetch()
1.0
traverse(invert=False)¶

Collect deeply nested values from incoming things matched by worker().

Parameters:invert (boolean) –

select incoming things that worker() evaluates as False rather than True

>>> class stooge:
...    name = 'moe'
...    age = 40
>>> class stooge2:
...    name = 'larry'
...    age = 50
>>> class stooge3:
...    name = 'curly'
...    age = 60
...    class stooge4(object):
...        name = 'beastly'
...        age = 969
>>> def test(x):
...    if x[0] == 'name':
...        return True
...    elif x[0].startswith('__'):
...        return True
...    return False
>>> # using worker while filtering for False values
>>> test.original().worker(test).traverse(invert=True).fetch()
[ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooges'), ('age', 40)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge2'), ('age', 50)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge3'), ('age', 60)]),
OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge4'), ('age', 969)]))]
undo(snapshot=0)¶

Restore incoming things to a previous snapshot.

Parameters:snapshot (integer) – number of steps ago e.g. 1, 2, 3 
>>> from knife import __
>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>> undone.append(1).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
>>> # undo back 2 steps
>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
unicode(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

unicode (str under Python 3) decode outgoing things.

Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) –

    error handling for decoding issues

    >>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.unicode().wrap_each().peek()
(u('[1]'), u('True'), u('t'), u('i'), u('g'), u('None'), u('(1,)'))
union()¶

Discover union within a series of iterable incoming things.

>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).union().fetch()
[1, 10, 3, 2, 101]
unique()¶

Discover unique incoming things.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).unique().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).worker(round).unique().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
weave()¶

Reduce multiple iterable incoming things to one iterable incoming thing by interleaving things found at the same index position within those iterables.

>>> test = __(['moe', 'larry'], [30, 40], [True, False])
>>> test.weave().fetch()
['moe', 30, True, 'larry', 40, False]
worker(worker)¶

Assign Python callable used to process incoming things.

Parameters:worker – a Python callable
wrap(wrapper)¶

Assign object, type, or class used to wrap outgoing things. The default wrapper is list.

Parameters:wrapper –

a Python object, type, or class

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).wrap(tuple).peek()
(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
wrap_each()¶

Toggle whether each outgoing thing should be individually wrapped with wrap() or whether all outgoing things should be wrapped with wrap() all at once. Default behavior is to wrap() everything at once.

zip()¶

Convert multiple iterable incoming things to tuples composed of things found at the same index position within those iterables.

>>> test = __(['moe', 'larry'], [30, 40], [True, False])
>>> test.zip().fetch()
[('moe', 30, True), ('larry', 40, False)]
